t: Job 32
Elihu
So*p these three men stopped answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
But Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job for justifying himself rather than God.
He was also angry with the three friends, because they had found no way to refute Job, and yet had condemned him.
Now Elihu had waited before speaking to Job because they were older than he.
But when he saw that the three men had nothing more to say, his anger was aroused.
So*p Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite said: “I*pn am young in years, and*ld you are old; that*ln is why I was fearful, not*ld daring to tell you what I know.
I*ln thought, ‘Age should speak; advanced*ld years should teach wisdom.’
But*ln it is the spirit in a person, the*ld breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.
It*ln is not only the old who are wise, not*ld only the aged who understand what is right.
“Therefore*pn I say: Listen to me; I*ld too will tell you what I know.
I*ln waited while you spoke, I*ld listened to your reasoning; while*ln you were searching for words,
I*ld gave you my full attention. But*ln not one of you has proved Job wrong; none*ld of you has answered his arguments.
Do*ln not say, ‘We have found wisdom; let*ld God, not a man, refute him.’
But*ln Job has not marshaled his words against me, and*ld I will not answer him with your arguments.
“They*pn are dismayed and have no more to say; words*ld have failed them.
Must*ln I wait, now that they are silent, now*ld that they stand there with no reply?
I*ln too will have my say; I*ld too will tell what I know.
For*ln I am full of words, and*ld the spirit within me compels me;
inside*ln I am like bottled-up wine, like*ld new wineskins ready to burst.
I*ln must speak and find relief; I*ld must open my lips and reply.
I*ln will show no partiality, nor*ld will I flatter anyone;
for*ln if I were skilled in flattery, my*ld Maker would soon take me away.
